site_name: County of Essex Turtle Back Zoo

citations.narrative:
Two adult male California sea lions housed in the same enclosure had injuries to the head/neck area attributed to bites
due to fighting. The inspector observed, via photographs provided by zoo staff, two-2-to-3-inch white lines that appeared
to be healed lacerations on the left side of the face below the eye and ear, and lateral to the mouth on the sea lion ‘Zeus’.
According to the keeper log dated 8/19/22, it was noted that there were facial injuries on the two adult male sea lions
(‘Porter’ and ‘Zeus’) and that ‘both intact males currently were in rut’. The log further states that the adult male ‘Zeus’ “did
not participate the rest of the day but was visual at a distance.” Medical documentation indicated that ‘Zeus’ had a loss of
appetite for a few days. ‘Zeus’ was placed on pain medication for 3 days and directions to flush the wounds were given by
the attending veterinarian.
Marine mammals that are not compatible must not be housed in the same enclosure. Marine mammals must not be
housed near other animals that cause them unreasonable stress or discomfort or interfere with their good health. The
facility must ensure that sea lions that physically harm other animals are appropriately separated or are environmentally,
behaviorally, or medically managed to mitigate the chance of physical injury. The facility must ensure that physical
attacks are prevented for the health and well-being of all of the resident sea lions.
TO BE CORRECTED: FROM THIS DATE FORWARD (11-3-22)
This inspection and exit briefing were conducted with the facility representatives.
End Section

narrative:
3.109  Critical
   
Separation. 
Two adult male California sea lions housed in the same enclosure had injuries to the head/neck area attributed to bites 
due to fighting.  The inspector observed, via photographs provided by zoo staff,  two-2-to-3-inch white lines that appeared 
to be healed lacerations on the left side of the face below the eye and ear, and lateral to the mouth on the sea lion ‘Zeus’. 
According to the keeper log dated 8/19/22, it was noted that there were facial injuries on the two adult male sea lions 
(‘Porter’ and ‘Zeus’) and that ‘both intact males currently were in rut’. The log further states that the adult male ‘Zeus’ “did 
not participate the rest of the day but was visual at a distance.” Medical documentation indicated that ‘Zeus’ had a loss of 
appetite for a few days. ‘Zeus’ was placed on pain medication for 3 days and directions to flush the wounds were given by 
the attending veterinarian.  
 
Marine mammals that are not compatible must not be housed in the same enclosure. Marine mammals must not be 
housed near other animals that cause them unreasonable stress or discomfort or interfere with their good health. The 
facility must ensure that sea lions that physically harm other animals are appropriately separated or are environmentally, 
behaviorally, or medically managed to mitigate the chance of physical injury.  The facility must ensure that physical 
attacks are prevented for the health and well-being of all of the resident sea lions.

TO BE CORRECTED: FROM THIS DATE FORWARD (11-3-22) 
 
This inspection and exit briefing were conducted with the facility representatives. 
 
End Section
